Description: A dull brown pottery figure of a hippopotamus: repaired from two pieces with a large part of one side missing. The figure is crudely modelled with little detail, the eyes being shown by incised lines and the position of the ears being marked by two holes. Most of the mouth has been lost by the breaking away of the front of the face. The surviving parts of the figure are in good condition, and the missing portions have been restored in plaster.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Temple of Osiris-Khentimentu (Abydos), Bears excavator's mark M.69
Curator's comments: Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' II (London, 1902-4), pl.X, 225. Petrie says ('Abydos' II (London, 1902-4), 27) that this object was found in two pieces, one in the deposit M.65 and the other in M.89, but the figure itself bears the mark M.64. For similar figures, see W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' I (London, 1902), pl.LII, 35; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Abydos' II (London, 1902-4), pl.IX, 188;W. M. F. Petrie, 'Diospolis Parva : the cemeteries of Abadiyeh and Hu, 1898-9' (London, 1901), pl.VI. (R.134). For the date of this figure see E. Baumgartel, 'The cultures of prehistoric Egypt' II (London, OUP), 72.
